Posts.Content: Newly diagnosed, applied for life policy in June of 14, declined coverage due to PSA results, didn't even know what it meant my PSA was 18.5, two additional tests confirmed the same, last week results from biopsy confirmed presence of cancer with Gleason score of 7 (4+3) Ctpet scan completed last week, results to be reviewed next Tuesday with oncologist, no staging as of yet, additional referral to oncology Dr with bladder specialty, continue to educate myself to new terms, treatment options, reviewing these posts for those who have gone before me. Thanks for the shared wisdom. R
Posts.Title: Awaiting remaing tests

Posts.Content: I've checked pathology report but do not see any staging listed, left apex 4+3, left mid 3+3, left anterior 4+3, I am 63, no other health issues, I've had lower back pain for about six to eight months just throght it was age appropriate given my activity, it's increased and I'm getting fatigued with normal activity, so Tuesday's appointment with oncology should provide details of staging and if petct scan shows anything outside of prostrate, my urologist also added a referral to a second oncologist with specialty in bladder and prostrate, this came the morning after the scan, indicating something new, like so many it's the waiting until the next appointment and review of results.R
Posts.Title: Awaiting remaing tests

Posts.Content: Bone metstasic to spine and hips, no other locations showed on scans, reviewed recommended treatment plan with oncologist, and will finalize with urologist next week, with the high PSA number + my age + lower back pain plus Gleason of 7 i was not surprised but was hopeful it may be localized. My treatment my start as early as Nov 1, Ron
Posts.Title: Awaiting remaing tests

Posts.Content: Thanks for the welcome, as well as the encouragement, I will post results tomorrow night, I think the benefit of the wait for me is the education. I have had time to gain knowledge and an understanding of the nature of this DX (see already using medical terms) and the need for me to ask the questions of my doctors, myself, and those close to me, while I'm still in the process of determining what choice the treatment will involve I am certain of one thing, I want to be as aggressive as my body will tolerate now to have the best outcome in the years offered afterward, I cannot speak to the otherside of treatment, but do hope my memory is good enough to remember I choose life first, quality of life second, and possibly I may have both. Each day I take a medicine that came with a long list of possible side effects, it works for me in the intended way and I have not had any adverse effects, so I hope this is true of some of the treatments I've been reading about. Again thanks to all who share their journey and knowledge gained. Ron
